newsitem.title: SPAIN: TENNIS-ANGRY MUSTER CRASHES OUT TO PIOLINE.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-ANGRY MUSTER CRASHES OUT TO PIOLINE.

text.p: Reigning champion Thomas Muster crashed out of the Barcelona Open on Thursday after failing to cope with either the windy conditions or his temper in a straight-sets defeat by Cedric Pioline.
Muster broke his racquet on the ground after losing a first set tie-break and then responded to jeers by gesturing back to the crowd before finally losing the tie 7-6 6-4.
The Austrian had struggled in his first clay court game of the season on Tuesday, and against Pioline he once again looked short of practice on a surface which he has made his own.
"My game has changed a bit, I'm now better on hard courts, but I've got six weeks till Paris and the French Open," Muster said.
"I maybe played 20 percent under my level and sometimes that isn't enough. You can't play 48 weeks, all the tournaments well, and this time it happened in Barcelona."
"It was cold and it was windy, which I don't like," added Muster, whose problems were exacerbated by Pioline's probing baseline game.
The world number two and number one seed made a series of uncharacteristic unforced errors, and failed to put away some loose balls on crucial points.
Muster broke back from 3-1 down in the first set and looked to have clawed his way back into the match after forcing the tie-break.
But he lost his way after lobbing out after a thrilling 30-stroke rally that gave the Frenchman set point.
"I saw that Muster was nervous because I was playing well and when I won that point he saw that I could fight," said Pioline, who had never beaten Muster before.
The Austrian lost his way at that stage and broke his racquet in disgust after losing the tie-break 7-4.
Muster responded to jeers in characteristically belligerant fashion by gesturing like a conductor asking for more volume from an orchestra.
"(I broke it) because I was so happy at that moment," Muster said ironically. "The crowd pay money and they can do whatever they want."
The second set went with serve until 5-4 when Pioline clinched victory on the second of two match points.
Pioline, seeded 16, faces a quarter-final match against Albert Costa, who was given a walkover after Germany's Marc Goellner withdrew with a fever.
If he beats Pioline, Costa will join fellow Spaniard Carlos Moya in the world's top ten.
Earlier Moya had been made to fight by unknown Moroccan Hicham Arazi.
"The game was not easy. He's got a difficult game with strange spins and the wind was difficult for both of us," the Australian Open finalist said.
Moya faces a quarter-final clash against Andrei Medvedev, who needed three sets to end the run of qualifier Alberto Martin.
Another qualifier, Albert Portas, continued to upset the odds with a 7-5 3-6 6-1 win over compatriot Fernando Vicente.
Portas is set to face Morocco's Karim Alami on Friday. The winner will fill a semifinal berth against either Brazilian Fernando Meligeni or former French Open finalist Alberto Berasategui.
Ninth-seeded Berasategui came back from 4-1 down in the first set to dispatch fellow Spaniard Felix Mantilla 7-6 6-1.
